Posts.Content: Hello Dolina, not exactly the the same as you but  I had a tumour found in breast but an ultrasound, MRI and CT showed no abnormalities  in the lymph nodes.  until they did a lumpectomy and sentinal node biopsy then 1 node was found to have a large deposit so I had lymph node clearance too. now waiting for radiotherapy but that is to zap the breast where the initial tumour was. I asked about the armpit and they said no cancer would be there as all lymph nodes taken. sorry probably not much help! jac x
Posts.Title: Can anyone help me please with lymph node question please.

Posts.Content: Hi Foxglove65  sorry to hear your diagnosis. I had lumpectomy but was never given these options so hopefully someone will come along to help more specifically. I just had a choice of where the scar would be. So opted for round the areola rather than across my boob. Pleased I did as you can hardly see that scar now. I do have a scar where they did the SNB and that is visible but getting better day by day.  I was told that they could do lipofilling if the size/shape was an issue in the future which I think involves fat transfer. I’m not at that stage yet as still have swelling . good luck and I hope someone is able to help
Posts.Title: Lumpectomy options help please!

Posts.Content: Hi Julie, it is another minefield. I wasn't eligible on the NHS for the omcotype DX as I had cancer in my lymph nodes, only 1 out of 19 but under NICE guidelines I'm ineligible. obviously I was comcerned that going down the rads route only would not give me complete belt and braces approach. However there are other reasons in play as to why they would suggest chemo or not and whether they would do oncoytpe DX to see. my tumour was very slow growing and non aggressive based on size, Ki 67 score HER 2 - and hormone positive status. at 44 it was thought that the risks of chemo would outweigh the benefit. it is a question to put to your team, as I did when I found out about it, and they can clear up any confusion or concerns. best wishes
Posts.Title: I e been asked today what my Oncotype DX Test result was by a friend...

Posts.Content: Hi, i worked with Paul Ellis way back when. He's a very personable chap and heavily into clinical trials so always at the forefront of latest drugs, combinations and treatments. not been a patient of his, and never thought I would be but I did consider contacting him when I had my BC diagnosis. Have been happy with my oncologist where I live though so didn't feel the need to trek into London Especially with kids still to organise!! vey best of luck with your journey
Posts.Title: Recommendations for an oncologist

Posts.Content: And again unfortunately  the ki67 isn't done everywhere either hence some people know about it and others  don't!  I went with my onc treatment plan of no chemo but did quiz on all of the things you have been asking about before I was happy! The BCN was good too as she put it in a different way too which helped make me happy with the treatment plan. i think they tell you what you think you need to know but with a whole internet  world out there and a fab site like this many of us are wanting to know more and more to get some control over our situations. I know that's what I wantEd. But I have overheard conversations in th breast clinic of people who really don't and are happy to just go with what they are told and not question, which is fine too.
Posts.Title: I e been asked today what my Oncotype DX Test result was by a friend...

Posts.Content: Glad to help, hope it works for you. I'm still using 4 weeks after Rads finished and all good. my daughter only used the green oatmeal based one for her excema as that was only one around back then, but she uses it still now as she does have sensitive skin still. good luck with the radiotherapy
Posts.Title: ☢☢☢ April 2018 Radiotherapy Club ☢☢☢

Posts.Content: I suspect there is more than one reason for boosters. Mine were definitely to get to the deeper tumour site. The area zapped for the 3 I had was a lot smaller and didn't go near the armpit. I even had a smaller darker triangle of tanned skin where they zapped. Dreamthief you have amazed me with your knowledge and lovely posts, can you shed light on radiotherapy boosters please?
Posts.Title: ☢☢☢ April 2018 Radiotherapy Club ☢☢☢

Posts.Content: Hi jacks77 glad you've got a bit of a break before radiotherapy. Do you think the chemo has dried out your skin or have you always suffered with dry skin? Just wondering now if it was th chemo things may improve for you. on the Aveeno front which one ar you using? I found the one with green cap and writing not as good as the "skin relief" one which has blue cap and writing on it. Still using it now twice a day! I tried the aloe gel and kept in fridge and although was very good at soothing the hot skin I didon't find it very good at moisturising so maybe watch that. hope you go well with GP though and getting the R1 R2 creams.
Posts.Title: ☢☢☢ April 2018 Radiotherapy Club ☢☢☢

Posts.Content: Hi Jackie, glad you managed to get the creams. I had 3 boosters and asked why and was told because the tumour site was deep in my breast so wanted extra localised zaps to ensure reached. I'm a C cup so not huge and my tumour was 19mm. I suspect is therefore due to size of boob, site of the tumour and how big tumour was. I was Grade 2. do ask radiologist on Monday though that's what they are there for
Posts.Title: ☢☢☢ April 2018 Radiotherapy Club ☢☢☢

Posts.Content: Hi @queenfisher, sorry not sure why not tagging! I had a cough during rads and they said to keep going ( but that was in the middle). They said I had to not move my hands though to cover mouth if I wanted to cough and to just cough into the air! It may be an idea to give them a call today to see if you can delay start as it is hard lying on your back for a cough. Equally I really don't think they'd mind if you went tomorrow and discussed it with them first and made a decision whether to go ahead or not. In the meantime, lemon and honey? Hope you feel better soon
Posts.Title: ☢☢☢ April 2018 Radiotherapy Club ☢☢☢

Posts.Content: Hi there, i used Aveeno throughout rads. It's not aloe based.  We discovred this cream when my dauughter had severe escema when she was younger and really helped. you can get 2 types a green lettered one which is oatmeal based  and a blue lettered one Which is labeeled as their "skin relief" range Not sure or the exact differences. I used both and found the blue one better it's called "skin relief".
Posts.Title: ☢☢☢ April 2018 Radiotherapy Club ☢☢☢

Posts.Content: Hi @lucy-b sorry to hear but it's doable....pretty much same results as me back in November. I've just come to end of radiotherapy last week and trying to find my new normal. take one day at a time and do keep busy in bewtween, takes your mind off things. Have they told you your homone status or HER2? It does have an impact on treatment but it's early days so not to worry if you don't know yet. They will find out more after lumoectomy as you say. I suspect you're waiting on a date for that. any questions or reassurance everyone is here for you take care
Posts.Title: Test Results

Posts.Content: Shirl, sorry to hear youre still in pain. It does make it all so tiring and harder to deal with especially with the lack of sleep. hope you get some good help at your appointment.
Posts.Title: Swelling after 8 days free lumpectomy

Posts.Content: Hi Shirl does sound like a seroma. I call mine the alien and it's currently pregnant again! Having it drained in the morning. supposedly starting rads week after and already had planning before it grew so big so now they're trying to get it under control. I think they like to leave it if possible to right itself, but I'm now 6 weeks post surgery so it's not doing that!  MArgo glad to hear yours is starting to get smaller! jac x
Posts.Title: Swelling after 8 days free lumpectomy

Posts.Content: My incicsion was the same, around nipple and glued. I used a gentle soap, sanex sensitive I think. And washed gently. The glue was starting to peel so was annoying me. I also used cream afterwards quite early on as I got very dry skin and looked like I was peeling. I found the glue pretty resilient. The blue nipple lasted for sometime but has gone now. i think you'll be alright using E45. When the glue had gone I also used hyericum calendula balm directly on the scar and any sore bits of skin and it healed very well. take care
Posts.Title: Dry skin/healing

Posts.Content: Hi Jen, i didn't have a mastectom, I had WLE and then full node clearance. I have had intermittent rib pain on the same side ever since. I have mentioned it to the BCN who thinks it's due to th nerves and muscles on that side bing damaged during th op.  So,e days it's just a dull contiunous ache others thy feel bruiepsed to touch. im monitoring it for now as I had a full body CT which was clear so it's only my heard going into overdrive as to what it could be other than nerve and muscle pain!! I also have a winged scapula which makes shoulder very stiff too. Have been referred to Physio for that. What a pair we are!! probably worth mentioning to your team best wishes
Posts.Title: Rib pain after mastectomy

Posts.Content: Morning, I researched seroma to death a few months ago and what I came to th conclusion was that one size does not fit all!  Draining helps some and not others, some get infected and not others, etc etc. Mine was tennis ball size in my armpit Post ANC. I had it drained 3 times and each time a very red liquid came out. I was concerned as I thought it was supposed to be straw coloured but they reassured me that it was old blood mixed in and needed to come out. I then went for radiotherapy and alien seroma caused a few issues as it changed th shape of my contours so between planning and the first zap the change was too big so they had to rescan and mark up again for rads. I was told not to get drained through rads and all went ahead with additional CTs during to double check. Now here was where I seem to have been lucky and the rads helped shrink the seroma. All I can feel now ( and I’m now 3 months Post end of rads) is a very small hard lump under my Axillary scar. Hope you manage to find relief from your seromas soon
Posts.Title: I still have a large seroma 5 months after my surgery

Posts.Content: Morning OCRKate i had an itchy nipple after Radiotherapy and went a bit flakey too so could be the start of a side effect of the rads. When did you finish? My side effects from the rads were worst about 10 days after then they started to improve. Was also lucky and had relatively mild side effects. i was given IntraSite gel by the radiotherapist. Can you speak to your rads team perhaps and get them to check it out?
Posts.Title: Itchy Nipple - Normal or Something Bad?

Posts.Content: Hi Cannykie50  i wasn’t  given any special bra or in fact any bra advise at all following lumpectomy. I didn’t wear anything to bed other than pjs and could only manage a soft crop top style bra in the day as the skin was so sensitive. thankfully recovered well post lumpectomy and all swelling in breast reduced. I did have a seroma in th arm pit but no bra would have compressed that area so wasn’t much I could do. Unfortunately during radiotherapy my boob swelled up a little and hasn’t gone back so I have suspected lymphedema of the breast now....appointment next  week to confirm and see what I can do about it. I have been wearing sports bras for the last few weeks and I’m getting very annoyed but there’s no pain or really much discomfort. all the best with your op.....don’t forget to do your exercises after!
Posts.Title: 3 weeks post WLE and SNB

Posts.Content: I agree with mistymoley not necessarily too long past end of rads. Problem we have now is trying not to think the worst.  Let. Us know how you get on and fingers crossed for simple resolution
Posts.Title: Itchy Nipple - Normal or Something Bad?

Posts.Content: It’s the waiting and what ifs. I tended to just get up after trying in vain to go back to sleep. Put TV on and emerge myself in crap viewing! Then I was lucky as kids are teens and take themselves to school so I could stay in pjs on sofa all day some days dozing. But what I did find helped was keeping myself busy in day, meeting friends, sport etc. Lots of walking to wear myself out.  I am now finished with treatment and 6 months down the line I am now sleeping again. May be side effects of radiotherapy helping but I’m not complaining!! There is an end but during you need to try and go with the flow a bit. There is als the AWAKE thread for those up and needing company in the silly hours of the night too  Lots of hugs
Posts.Title: Just diagnosed with breast cancer

Posts.Content: Morning, That is so true about how do you ask the right questions when you’ve no idea what they are about to say to you! However that is why you get a BCN so you can phone and ask away.  I seem d to always have Thur appointments, would mull itniver the week nd and then call on Monday. Regarindg the ER PR status yes this is whether the tumour is hormon e positive and will define if you get hormone treatment after surgery etc. The other receptor they test for is HER-2. This is either -ve or +ve and again will dertermine treatment you receive, ie Herceptin treatment if +ve Don’t want to bombard you but one other thing you may want to find out about is your Ki67 score. Not all trusts seem to do this but it can show the aggressiveness of the tumour and again help with treatment plan.  When do you go back for next appointment? Do phone your BCN though they are there for all these questions Take care
Posts.Title: Just diagnosed with breast cancer

Posts.Content: Hi there, it is a hard decision to make. I can only offer you may treatment plan which is similar. I was Grade 2 19mm and had lumpectomy and cancer found in 1 of 3 nodes taken out, I was strongly advised to have Axillary clearance and had to level 2 after some negotiation as they were going to take to level 3.  A further 16 nodes were taken and were all clear, phew! the onco type is not offered on the NHS if nodes are positive, but based on my results of ER +, HER- and a low Ki 67 score I dodged the chemo train and went straight to rads. axilary clearance op I found handed to recover from compar d to thbe lumpectomy and you do have an added risk of lymphedema, but you also do if you have rads to the Axillary area. So far so good in the lymphedema stakes and if I had to do it again I wouldn't change the treatment plan I had. i am in the position though who I can also have tamoxifen with it being hormone positive. hopefully some others will also come along with their advice too to give you as much of a pictur as possible for you to make an informed decision. I do advise to keep talking with your BCN, no question is silly and that's what they are thereee for. good luck and hugs
Posts.Title: Results following BC op

Posts.Content: Oh good news you got to see your surgeon. As I said before I had this decision to make in Dec last year. My surgeon said there was no difference on risks of lymphedema whether I had surgery or radiotherapy to the area. But he did say things were looking more favourable for not going ahead with ANC but as results not all in he didn't want to risk it so after further discussions we decided just on removing levels 1 and 2 lymph nodes. This means that level 3 still there and can hopefully mop up any cancer that may ( hopefully not) appear in the future. so I'm coming to 6 months down and no lymphedema to date. I am careful with not lifting heavy things and I moisturise daily and carry germolene and insect bite cream around with me. All other activities are back to normal. at the end of the day it is such a personal decision to make. I was happy I went ahead as I was pretty paranoid more lymph nodes could have cancer in them and I wanted it all out!! did your surgeon give any preference as to what you should do....perhaps a "if this was your wife or daughter what would you advise"?? sending lots of good wishes and hugs your way
Posts.Title: Results following BC op

Posts.Content: Hello again All your questions were exactly what I went through before deciding too. I stayed in overnight after op but only due to anaesthetic issues ( I also stayed in after lumpectomy). I had a drain for a week and this was still Draining when removed but I had quite a sore side and shoulder and thought the drain was contributing so asked for it tot be removed and they were fine with that. The pain immediately subsided so was right decisions I did need codeine after op And for a couple of days but stopped when got too constipated! Managed then on paracetamol and ibuprofen. Exercises really important and were fine to do after about day 2. I did develop a seroma about tennis ball size at its biggest, had drained 3 times before radiotherapy. During rads they had to do extra CT scans to check size but was all fine. It has subsided since with no further treatment but did take about 3-4 months. Was never painful just uncomfortable. I have since been to a lyohedema specialist privately who assessed arm And did baseline measurements. All are good and she thinks I only have a slim chance of developing lymphedema. She prescribed a sleeve and I wear it whenever out walking or doing sport, tennis, yoga and hockey. But I DO NOT have lymphedema. Regards the trial I was told that although there is a trial ongoing to see if further node removal is warranted the results aren’t in yet so the standard is still to remove under NICE guidelines. ( this was DEC 2017 so may be further info out how) In my mind I wanted any nasties left gone so mentally was the right decision for me. I am now 5 months since op And 2 months end of rads. I have full arm movement, but can feel the stretch but in a good way. My boob is still Swollen from rads but only the intermittent  pains expected with nerves etc still mending.  Seroma likes to make an appearance after exercise but not sore so I ignore it!! It is all doable but if I can answer any other questions please let me know Bets wishes
Posts.Title: Results following BC op

Posts.Content: Hi mistymoley  i believe that the progesterone is a factor too as my tumour was  ER+ and PR + so I think they like to ensure progesterone levels are minimised too.

How oftern do you wear your sleeves now? thamks again and best wishes

Pain was unbelievable in shoulder and couldn't lift arm at all. However drain came out the day after and it's been "almost" plain sailing since. It is harder than the first op I think. I seem to have more aches around the back/shoulde blade. Like muscle pain/weakness. Can now do all the exercises though so hopefully will get stronger. It's the waiting game again for the both of us. My tumour wa grade 2 too, but seems to be on smaller side from yours. Fingers crossed for us both. Take care Jac

Posts.Title: Axillary Node Clearence

Posts.Content: Morning and Happy New Year, Had some good news finally, just spoke to lovely breast nurse who let me know the path report from Axillary clearance 2 weeks ago shows no cancer found, so relieved! Chemo not ruled out completely due to my young age But we can have a discussion when I see the oncologist. To be honest though I think I'll get me head round it if they do advise it and suck it up. This ain't beating me!! Good luck to any one else getting results now we're past the back holidays and lots of love to you all. Jac xx
Posts.Title: Axillary Node Clearence

Posts.Content: Hello Sarah, Sorry you find yourself in a similar position. I don't remember exactly where I found the info about the ability to limit the modal clearance to just levels 1 and 2 but I also have a friend who has gone through similar treatment and she has been an invaluable support. My reasons to push for it was 2 fold at the time. - limit the risk of lymphedema as much as possible and also if another tumour was found in breast down the line ( hell I hope not!) potentially leaving some nodes in place would mop up any cancer cells before they got round rest of body. I then contacted my breast nurse who contacted the surgeon on my behalf and asked. He was happy to leave level 3 and treat conservatively. He also said there was argument to just take level 1 but as the tumor in the node was sizeable at 3mm he would take levels 1 and 2. I'm now heading down the chemo route before radiotherapy which has been a shock. First appointment with oncologist to discuss regimen next week......may I ask what chemo you had? Anything I should ask? Putting a list together!! Good luck with your decision. This cancer crap is a mindfield!! Take care Jac x
Posts.Title: Axillary Node Clearence

Posts.Content: Morning, I hadn't had neo adjuvant chemo so felt that there was nothing mopping up,at the time any cancer cells remaining.  As the node had a 3mm deposit I felt I wanted others removed to make sure no others were affected. Thankfully all others came back clear. I had 17 removed in total. Recovery has been slower than after the WLE. But I'm 3 weeks post op today and have full range of movement in my arm, albeit a bit stiff ( but not painful). Numbness still very apparent but it's a weird felling rather than anything else. And it is slowly coming back. I do have an issue with my scapula which I'm seeing a Physio about today. The nerve was damaged but not severed that holds th muscle to the scapula so I'm just seeking further advice on how to help this recover. It has already improved. Risk of lymphedema still scares me but I'm coming to terms with it and doing every I can to prevent it occurring. I have learnt a lot about cancer and myself and how I feel about things over the last few months. It's definitely a personal path. I am 44 and my logic is that I don't want this cancer coming back. If I don't throw everything they suggest at it now and it comes back in 5 years I will be devastated. Best wishes all Jac x
Posts.Title: Axillary Node Clearence

Posts.Content: Hi sarah, It is sooo hard, but whatever you decide it will be right for you as you are doing all you can to find out the pros and cons of your options. I have never regretted the decisions made, for me and by me, so far, hope that continues.  I am at just over 3 weeks post Axillary clearance at the moment and there is still plenty of numbness under arm and down back of top arm. To be honest it really doesn't bother me. Im at the itching stage where the nerves are doing their best at recovering and can only assume this is good regarding the numbness as it is still improving. There is a chance there will be long term numbness but for me I am not worried as it doesn't seem to affect me with respect to what I can do with my arm. I developed a seroma a few days after the drains came out but a week later and that has resolved on its own, phew! The Physio really helped this week and I've a whole range of new exercises to do now to get the scapula and muscles back to normal. He was very positive and doesn't think I'll  have lasting problem. I'm a tennis player so need my playing arm back to normal so I can play again.....this is my focus at the moment as I'm determined to get back out there in the next week or so. It is helping me have a goal at the moment as chemo is looming! Good luck and best wishes Jac x
Posts.Title: Axillary Node Clearence

Posts.Content: Hi Joanne, I think I'm a week ahead of you. had WLE and SNB on 22nd Nov and then auxiliary clearance 2 days ago. This second op has certainly been more constricting  in the arm movement and only today have I been able to attempt th exercises. After last op I recovered really quickly and was playing tennis again with the affected arm after 3 weeks. You may want to check what level clearance they are going to do. I had one node with a 3mm tumour found out of 3 removed. I had a CT to check staging and thankfully was found to be all clear. I posed the question whether levels 1-3 all needed to be removed and the surgeon said he was happy to be more conservative so took just levels 1 and 2. This reduces risk of lymphedema slightly and also leaves nodes in as if further lumps found in the future leaving nodes may help prevent  further spread. Onviously we are all different and decisions need to be done individually but hope this helps. A V shaped cushion is fab...they gave me one on the ward, apparently lovely volunteers make them. Also my mum made me a drain Dollie bag. So I can walk around with the drain and have hands free. I am keeping on top of things with pain meds still so don't have experience yet of level of pain without them!! Fingers crossed it doesn't all kick in on Xmas Day !! All the best for the 27 th Jac x
Posts.Title: Axillary Node Clearence

Posts.Content: Hope your now recovering well Jammy. Can anyone help, I'm a week post axillary clearance (levels 1 and 2). Week to go till I get my results. I'm trying to come up with all the different scenarios and questions to ask and wondered if anyone knows the possibility of if chemo will be offered. I had a 19mm tumour, HER2 -, ER+ and had lumpectomy and SNB. 1 node came back with a 3 mm tumor hence the ALND.  If all nodes come back clear I suspect I will have radiotherapy only ( as per discussion with surgeon before last op) however if cancer is found in any of the lymph nodes they took last week is chemo an option or advised first? Anyone able to help with their experiences please? Thank you
Posts.Title: Axillary Node Clearence

Posts.Content: evening all, i went to see a lymphedema specialist yesterday for an assessment. I don't have lymphedema but do still have a large seroma under my Axilla scar so wanted to see if she could help with that. She has done arm measurements on both arms and there is a couple of larger measurements on my bad side but not enough to warrant a lymphedema diagnosis. It's all about percentages and mine is low. the long and short is no she can't help the seroma as it is a pocket of lymph and does not respomd to lymphatic massage, but she will see me again after my radiotherapy has finished to help with scar tissue reduction to see if that will release the seroma. what she has done is suggest I wear a compression sleeve when I go out walking or shopping or for any length of time my arm is just hanging down. She's written a letter to give to my GP to get one on prescription. so my question is does anyone else wear one or have been advised to wear one as a preventative measure?  Many thanks for reading and any advise
Posts.Title: Compression sleeve for prevention?

Posts.Content: Hi again, I too was worrying right up to op if I was making right decision. It is hard. Do you have a breast nurse? I phoned mine just the day before op and asked questions ( namely which level nodes they were taking and also as CT was clear was ANC still necessary) she went straight to surgeons to clarify and called me back. They had discussed all at The MDT the day before and I was happy with the decision. I even clarified everything on day of op with the surgeon who was more than happy to talk it all through. Try not to worry and enjoy tomorrow Jac xx
Posts.Title: Axillary Node Clearence

Posts.Content: Doh! Yes of course she will be sorry. 4 days post op can I be forgiven for not having a brain?? I went with what the MDT decided and am happy with that. Pleased to say movement in arm is massively better already.  Drain still in but not bothering me  Good luck Wed  Jac xx
Posts.Title: Axillary Node Clearence

Posts.Content: Thanks Lynn, I looked at the oncotype test but doesn't look like I'll be eligible as it's not offered if lymph nodes involved and I'm Pre menopausal at 44. Posts.Title: Axillary Node Clearence

Posts.Content: Hi Taralou, Im still pretty swollen from the surgery, feels like I have something solid permanently in the way under my arm!  You can get something called a seroma which is a build up of fluid after the  drain is removed. It can go on it's own or you can get it drained. Maybe worth a call to your team if no better in day or so perhaps? Im not sure about lymphedema, it is always on my mind too. Keep doing the exercises and  perhaps very gentle massage/ stroking.  Take care Jac
Posts.Title: Axillary Node Clearence

Posts.Content: You know what Joanne I was sooo relieved no cancer left, had a little cry, phoned husband and sister.  BUt until I see surgeon on Thursday and then the oncologist I still feel unsettled. I'm the type of person who needs a plan and at the moment it's still a bit up in the air. Abbie999 I'm going to attempt to drive tomorrow, kids back at school so will be on my own for th first time and will not want to be in the house on my own that's for sure! Only 2 weeks down the line so still swollen but think it's all healing OK. I agree it's uncomfortable rather than painful. All the best everyone
Posts.Title: Axillary Node Clearence

Posts.Content: Hi Pointer i have been in virtually same boat and ii was absolutely gutting. After that appointment I went to all future ones with worse case scenario in my head to aim to limit how crap I felt. i had cancer in my sentinel nodes too and went on to have ANC, exactly a month after first op and 3 days before Xmas last year. Thankfully for me my margins were ok. Pleased to say that no further cancer was found in the 17 further nodes taken but was still relief to know they were taken out in case.  It does set you back mentally but you will get your head round it and once all details and plans in place again you can focus on your recovery and hopefully next steps of radiotherapy. keep yourself busy and stay on here, we can virtually support you
Posts.Title: Second Operation

Posts.Title: Flying while on tamoxifen

Posts.Content: Hi again, ive sent a message to ask the expert, thanks Leolady56 as I understand the problem with tamoxifen and I’m not sure if this is for letrozole too is the risks of blood clots which when flying is obviously compounded. i think from what I have heard and read so far I will just take all the precautions normally given to anyone rat risk egarding DVT and flying wear flight compression socks wear my lymphedema sleeve take aspirin walk around drink lots  i have read through the leaflet again and nowhere does it mention additional risk when flying. thanks all for your replies and happy holidays xx
Posts.Title: Flying while on tamoxifen

Posts.Content: Hi thought id update you on the flight!! Spoke with GP before I left and he said that the risk is only increased whilst on Tamoxifen if you are already predisposed to blood clots in the first place. He said taking 75mg aspirin day before, day of flight and day after would not hurt but was up to me. so I deceid3d to take the aspirin and I wore flight socks and my lymphedema sleeve. 4hours in and my hand starts to feel odd and cold so I started clenching and unclenching it. I had been drinking lots of water and going to the toilet or for a stretch every hour. The hand had swollen completely so I took the sleeve off. Was in a slight panic and on my own so no one to chat to. Thankfully within about half hour of being offf plane hand returned to normal. flight home I left the sleeve off.....will discuss next time I see specialist!! On taking socks off feet were pudgy but settled down quickly......maybe I’m just predisposed to swelling up!!!! happy flying everyone. I had a fantastic weekend in New York, suffering a bit today from jet lag....but oh so worth it

Posts.Title: Crafts and BC

Posts.Content: Hi there, have you had follow up with your surgeon or is this first appointment after surgery? After my lumpectomy and SNB cancer was found in my lymph nodes so I had to have further surgery but if you already know your results th next steps should be what your next treatment will be. ( chemo/rads/hormone therapy or nothing). My surgeon initially confirmed all results as to size, Grade, etc. I was also told chemo was next step.....although this wasn't correct. at first oncologist appointment she went through again all the results and said chemo would not be required. She showed me the NHS predict score which was less than 5% benefit so not worth the risks of chemo. So the plan was then made for next steps which in my case was radiotherapy and tamoxifen fro 10years! she also assessed my readiness for radiotherapy based on recovery from surgery and booked me in with the radiotherapy team and gave me my first prescription for Tamoxifen. hope that makes sense, do keep asking questions as I always find the best way to be in control is to learn as much as possible good luck and take care

Posts.Title: tamoxifen(Nolvadex-d) and hair lost - need comments please

Posts.Content: Hello there, i had this second operation exactly a month after the WLE and SNB. And  was 3 days before Christmas last year! It is doable but I would say took me longer to recover from. I had a drain in for about 5 days and once that was out I felt loads better. The exercises are an absolute must and days I didn’t do them I noticed my arm feeling more stiff. there are more risks associated with ANC but I was happy to move forward knowing that any critters would be well and truly gone at the end. I have spoken since to another surgeon who said things are changing and a full clearance is not always warranted but it’s all decided on an individual bases so if you are not sure go back and ask more questions, ask what would be an alternative or % risk of not doing anything.  My results came back all clear after having a further 17 nodes taken out, but I still don’t regret my decision. I did develop a large seroma which was more annoying than painful and is pretty much resolved. A recent ultrasound shows there’s a pocket of fluid still but I don’t notice it at all.  The lymphedma risks are now higher however my arm is so far so good. Unfortunately I have developed oedema in my breast but this is attributable to radiotherapy rather than the op. Again it is annoying but not painful and not stopping me from doing anything anymore! finally during the op one of the nerves that attached muscle to my scapula was damaged so I did have a “winged scapula”  but other than being sore to raise arm up above head no lasting damage as Physio sorted that quite quickly. i am now 7months down the line from the op and 4months post end of treatment I would say I’m 90%back to me and still going in right direction. all this BC stuff is a steep learning curve and what I know now to 8months ago is phenomenal. Do not beat yourself up about any decision but have to be comfortable moving forward with the decisions you make for YOU and you only. hope this helps a little, take care

Posts.Title: Something I’d like to share

Posts.Content: Hi Pixie, i felt in a similar situation to you this time last year. Not the same cancer type, mine was ductal and in a node. My % benefit to having chemo was also just 3% and my oncologist would not advise chemo unless the benefit was 5% or higher as she felt the risks of chemo outweighed the benefits.. I though as was found in my nodes it was automatic chemo but I had full ANC and all other nodes were negative. i struggled as just wanted to throw everything at it, relatively young at 45, I thought I would cope better than if it returned when I was older.  I took all my concerns back to BCN a couple of days later and she was very helpful going through all my specific tumour parameters and she allayed my fears so I was more comfortable in my head about moving on without the chemo. So far no regrets and a year on I had the all clear before Christmas. A suggestion would be to  approach your team with your concerns/questions until you have all answered satisfactorily to be able to move on.  Bestwishes to you

Posts.Title: Can anyone tell me about their experience of lipomodelling please...

Posts.Content: Hi Sharon, i had macrometastese in 1 of 3 nodes taken so according to NICE guidelines last year the next steps are complete node removal. I was very unsure what to do here as the risks of lymphedema are higher. I did opt for the complete removal of levels 1and 2 and asked them to leave 3 alone! And no further nodes tested positive for macro or micro mets. Some surgeons don’t advocate node removal as it’s not a nice op. And I think for micromets it is considered overkill. i wa also told and I looked at the stats myself too that chemo risks would outweigh any benefit and after some mental torment I went with the advice or oncologist and had radiotherapy only.  Ive just had my one year mammogram and awaiting the results not very patiently!
Posts.Title: micrometastasis

Posts.Content: Smoo it's completly normal. Can you take yourself away, grab someone and go for a walk, get some fresh air to try and calm yourself? The only way I have managed to cope with th anxiety and waiting is to keep myself as busy as possible. I try and fill up my days as much as possible. Today is jam packed as I have first oncologist appointment tomorrow which I'm s***ing ( sorry) a brick over. I have lost over a stone in weight and constantly have nervous stomach problems. But I am getting better at reducing  them.  It is awful but you are so normal. Sorry you are going through this and best wishes Jac x
Posts.Title: Feeling terrified

Posts.Content: Hello salley  im sorry you're experiencing such discomfort. I'm not too sure I can help. I had a seroma from 2 weeks post ANC in my arm pit area not boob. At its largest it was a bit painful and achey but paracetamol did help. I had it drained 3 times but then stopped through radiotherapy. Thankfully it seemed to deminish during the rads but I'm now 5 months down the line and still have a small seroma being stubborn. there is not a lot but wait and see with seroma. I aasked everywhere and everyone how to get rid of it. If it is sizeable and continuing to cause pain then draining I think is the best option But it also may be you need to try and put  up with it to get the body to absorb it. I would suggest you get back in touch with yyou ur BCN and see what advice they can give you.  I do hope it resolves for you soon hugs

Posts.Title: NICE draft guidelines on treatment of primary breast cancer

Posts.Content: Morning, when I was diagnosed 8months ago it was very hard to leave those dark thoughts parked somewhere very far away. It was constantly on my mind. I found this site early on but didn’t use it much. I found reading the information from others freaked me out even more. Took me a long time to be able to join in and keep calm at the same time. She may not be ready yet to see what’s out there. i was 44 when diagnosed and have 2 teenagers to look after so what kept me busy was them. And when they were at school I tried to fill my days with friends, exercise, treat lunches etc. Perhaps you could help by planning the odd day out, afternoon tea, cinema, shopping etc. Your Mum may not be the life and soul on these days out but it could help her fill the waiting.......which is the absolute pits, I’m sure all others will agree on here. the other milestone for me was when I had the surgery and the cancer was gone, until then I just thought it was growing and growing and takin me over.....it wasn’t as was quite slow growing but your thoughts are not always rational and that is completely understandable. all the best for your Mum and family x

Posts.Title: NICE draft guidelines on treatment of primary breast cancer

Posts.Content: Sorry Ask did not post to worry you at all. I dint read any or understand much of this until I had pretty much gone through all diagnosis and plan with oncologist. Am nearish the end with radiotherapy left to conquer. I have found reading over this, and certainly not all of it, with respect to my treatment so far very helpful. Thank fully it seems to echo precisely what my medical team have done and offered me for my specific cancer type and diagnosis. In fact I think my team have been even more cautious and thorough with respect to full body CTs that actually weren't indicated completely but certainly set my mind at ease. I'm sorry you are going through this, but echo what previous post says wrote all your questions down, take time during the appointment if you need to, theyshould wait for you to process the info. take someone with you too and make sure they know what you want to ask. Couple of times I forgot certain questions and my Hubbie piped up and saved the day, Take care  Jac x

Posts.Title: Op postponed!!

Posts.Content: Hi charlene70 I have been taking tamoxifen for just over a month. The side effects so far have been very manageable. For me I have felt just tired in the main. I also was very irrationally emotional last week but have not attributed totally to tamoxifen as was very tired through a bad sleep, had just completed my first week of rads and had my period! Tamoxifen for pre menopausal women can also cause bone thining  as does the AIs but for post menopausal ladies it has the opposite effect. I have looked into this in great detail as my Nan, Mum and aunt all had/have osteoporosis however from what I have read a balanced diet and exercise and possibly taking calcium supplements should help to avoid that side effect.  I hope this has helped it is a mimefiled of information that’s for sure!

Posts.Content: Hi optomistic this is a real concern of mine that there won't be an end to the constant fear and cancer on your mind. I'm only 4 months in and hoping radiotherapy starts next week to have an actual end date to treatment, but then what!! i did speak to a very good friend who went through this 4 years ago and she did say I can now go days, sometimes even weeks without thinking about it. So I do hope there is light at the end of the tunnel for us all . take care and keep busy! Maybe plan things to look forward to too.
Posts.Title: Down day

Posts.Content: Hi Sandy, i did not have mastectomy but did develop a seroma after and ANC op. I had it drained 3 times over 3 weeks and then embarked on radiotherapy and was told to leave it be or my measurements would be out. This caused a few issues as I had to keep having a CT through the treatment to check they were still targeting right place! They are frustrating things, I researched and asked for advice and they are really a law onto their own. If you drain them because they are huge and causing pain they are likely to come back. Your body needs to try and reabsorb it. So it’s a balance between trying to leave be and having drained to relieve the discomfort I’m afraid. Gentle massage/stroking may help, the fluid needs to find a new path. good luck and I do hope it’s rsolves for you soon

Posts.Content: Hello, everything crossed for your results tomorrow. I had SNB and then full node clearance where th y went in at same scar. Last op was Dec 2017. I developed a seroma which was hard and went into my armpit and directly under the scar there. I did have it drained a coupl of times but then had radiotherapy and they said to leave it be. I still have it, not so much painful as annoying and a bit uncomfortable. It is VERY slowly going down but I'm now over 3 months post op. They are stubborn things if it is a seroma. i was advised to watch for increased redness and hotness as potentially may be infection, but had none of that thank fully. At lest you can get it checked tomorrow. do let us know how you get on take care
